NATO 556

Actually I lied, I don't believe we should reinstate this failed piece of legislation. It was a bad idea back in 1994, it's an even worse idea now, because we know that it won't work.
 
 Some people will claim that the ban saved many lives and that it would have saved many more if we allowed it to become permanent, and they're also claiming that the police are now facing arms races with criminals armed with AK-47s. But let's look at this in a realistic manner.
 
 The ban on so called "assault weapons" was passed on September 13, 1994. After this point any new guns containing certain cosmetic features were banned from ownership.
 
 On February 28, 1997, three years after the law went into effect and supposedly "banned" these weapons from ownership, we had the North Hollywood Shootout, between the entire Los Angelas Police Department, and two bank robbers covered in body armor and armed with illegally procured AK-47s, M16s and at least one H&K-91, all with banned features like flash suppressors, bayonet lugs, folding stocks and pistol grips.
 
 On April 20, 1999, five years after the ban on "assault weapons" went into effect, we had the Columbine massacre, one of the weapons used in the killings was the TEC-9 pistol, which was also banned by the law.
 
 How do the supporters of the "assault weapons" ban address these points? They claim that the law saved many lives, but the most newsworthy shootings of the late 20th century occurred during the reign of this ban, and they used weapons that were supposed to be banned and "off the streets" and "out of the hands of criminals".
 
 We're ultimately left with two options here. Either the ban was foolproof and it truly did save many lives, and North Hollywood and Columbine never took place in real life, or the ban was heavily flawed and did absolutely nothing to actually save lives. Two contrasting options, but only one can exist. Which is it?

NATO 556

The problem with trying to see the effects of a ban is that the only instances relevant to it are where it has failed. If it succeeds then there is not a noticeable 'event' to pick on - instead, the event that would have otherwise occurs never does.

 
 Exactly, there's no way to prove that a prohibition actually works. There's no tangible evidence to support the concept that these bans work, or that they're necessary for keeping crime rates down. And if you can't prove it in a scientific manner then how can you justify keeping it in place?
 
 It's kind of like arguing that God exists even though there's no hard scientific proof to support it.
 
 
I would be interested to see how 'assault weapons' have been used in illegal activities since/before the ban was lifted/set.

 
 The problem is that the definition of "assault weapon" is determined purely by cosmetic features that make no impact on the overall function of the weapon. So if a rifle with a bayonet lug qualifies as an "assault weapon" but the exact same rifle with the bayonet lug removed doesn't qualify as an "assault weapon" then the point is entirely moot.
iangb

Exactly, there's no way to prove that a prohibition actually works. There's no tangible evidence to support the concept that these bans work, or that they're necessary for keeping crime rates down. And if you can't prove it in a scientific manner then how can you justify keeping it in place?

 Sorry, I miss-spoke. It's impossible to prove that a prohibition works simply by looking at the events within the prohibition. Scientifically, the test is obvious, if very difficult to enact - set up (or find) two identical areas, let people carry guns in one and control them in the other. Compare, contrast, and repeat if possible. The problem is that finding two suitable areas is very hard - they not only have to be very similar, but they have to be suitably isolated for gun control to have an effect (for example: DC is a poor test case because any gun could simply be carried into the city from outside).
 
 
The problem is that the definition of "assault weapon" is determined purely by cosmetic features that make no impact on the overall function of the weapon. So if a rifle with a bayonet lug qualifies as an "assault weapon" but the exact same rifle with the bayonet lug removed doesn't qualify as an "assault weapon" then the point is entirely moot. 

 Indeed. I'm not particularly pro/anti the AW ban, because I would say that a regular firearm is just as easily misused. I was more fault-finding with your argument than trying to propose another ban - my position is to introduce stricter control (mandatory training/testing, list of gun licence owners, remove 'self-defence' as a valid reason for owning a gun), and pretty much leave it at that. Going on to a full gun ban might be a nice ideal, but it's not practical in today's America - even my current stance would have to be introduced slowly.

If they had been armed with knives and bombs alone (assuming their competence levels were unchanged), the casualty rate would have been much lower.

 
 How do you know for sure? Are you saying that you're less likely to be killed in a bombing than if you're shot at?
 
 
Knives are melee weapons, to not get stabbed you just have to stay out of reach. To not get shot, however, requires you to stay out of line-of-sight, which is much harder.

 
 I used to think the same thing, until I learned just how hard it is to actually shoot something. Simply pointing in the general direction of the target doesn't cut it.
 
 
I would say that there were probably other factors affecting school shootings in Israel, although I haven't looked into the matter fully.

 
 Then find the other factors that played a part in affecting the school killings in Israel.
 
 
Your animal analogy isn't particularly true. Firstly, it assumes that prey cannot suddenly become predators.

 
 Have you ever seen a fox or a wolf being chased away, all bloody and cut up after sneaking into a chicken house?
 
 
Secondly, it implies that foxes reason and plan rather than act on instinct. Thirdly - would you want to arm your chickens? Remember what you do to their (proto)children...

 
 They go for the weakest and the easiest to kill. Have you ever seen a predator decide it would rather eat the sheep dog instead of the sheep itself?
iangb

How do you know for sure? Are you saying that you're less likely to be killed in a bombing than if you're shot at?
No, I'm saying that in the case of Columbine, the killers had bombs, knives and guns. The bombs (largely) failed, and without the guns they would have been left with a knife 'massacre' - which, while possible, is much harder to achieve.
 
 
I used to think the same thing, until I learned just how hard it is to actually shoot something. Simply pointing in the general direction of the target doesn't cut it.

 And it's not all that easy to stab someone when they are in reach.
 
 
Have you ever seen a fox or a wolf being chased away, all bloody and cut up after sneaking into a chicken house?

 Exactly. Your analogy says one thing - but in reality, everyone is born a 'chicken' and only become wolves after they have committed a crime.
 
 I've also seen a snake killed by a mongoose. And heard of a wolf coming off worse against a skunk. Animals have mace-equivalent, too.
 
 
They go for the weakest and the easiest to kill. Have you ever seen a predator decide it would rather eat the sheep dog instead of the sheep itself?

 See above - inaccurate analogy.
NATO 556

No, I'm saying that in the case of Columbine, the killers had bombs, knives and guns. The bombs (largely) failed, and without the guns they would have been left with a knife 'massacre' - which, while possible, is much harder to achieve.

 
 If you want to play the assumption game then just say so. In that case, let's assume that the main bombs had gone off just as planned, just as the cafeteria had gotten full and was loaded with victims. Do you reasonably expect me to believe that a cafeteria full of students hit by a bomb would result in fewer fatalities than what did occur on that day?
 
 
And it's not all that easy to stab someone when they are in reach.

 
 It's not all that hard to stab someone either. Just walk up onto them while they're distracted, pull a knife and start stabbing while they're focused on somebody else, you'll get in a good number of wounds before they have a chance to get away. Or better yet grab them from behind and slit their throat to kill them immediately.
 
 
Exactly. Your analogy says one thing - but in reality, everyone is born a 'chicken' and only become wolves after they have committed a crime.

 
 And the point of this statement of yours is what? Better to remain a chicken all your life and let others come to your rescue? this isn't Metropolis, Superman isn't going to come swooping in to save you from the criminals whenever you scream for help. If you can't take care of yourself and you're alone then you're very likely going to die.
 
 
I've also seen a snake killed by a mongoose. And heard of a wolf coming off worse against a skunk. Animals have mace-equivalent, too.

 
 The mongoose is immune to snake venom; the equivalent to kevlar-lined clothing to us.
 
 
See above - inaccurate analogy.

 
 Inaccurate because you say so, or because you don't like it? I consider the analogy to be very accurate, and if you don't like it then you should prove why it's so wrong.
iangb

If you want to play the assumption game then just say so. In that case, let's assume that the main bombs had gone off just as planned, just as the cafeteria had gotten full and was loaded with victims. Do you reasonably expect me to believe that a cafeteria full of students hit by a bomb would result in fewer fatalities than what did occur on that day?

 I'm making realistic assumptions. Not having guns wouldn't have made the cafeteria bombs mysteriously start to work, all they would have done is left the killers with knives to kill with.
 
 
It's not all that hard to stab someone either. Just walk up onto them while they're distracted, pull a knife and start stabbing while they're focused on somebody else, you'll get in a good number of wounds before they have a chance to get away. Or better yet grab them from behind and slit their throat to kill them immediately.

 If you can do that with a knife, then you can do it with a gun in exactly the same way. A gun can also kill at range.
 
 
And the point of this statement of yours is what? Better to remain a chicken all your life and let others come to your rescue? this isn't Metropolis, Superman isn't going to come swooping in to save you from the criminals whenever you scream for help. If you can't take care of yourself and you're alone then you're very likely going to die.
 ...
 Inaccurate because you say so, or because you don't like it? I consider the analogy to be very accurate, and if you don't like it then you should prove why it's so wrong.

 I already mentioned my point - that this makes it an innacurate analogy.
 
 Your analogy is that if we could arm the chickens, then the foxes would stop attacking them. While this may be true, it also will have the effect of further arming the foxes, and encouraging more chickens to turn into foxes. We could also suitably defend the chickens by methods that do not stand open to abuse - extra fencing, putting a skunk amongst them, etc...
 
 Like I said, poor analogy.
 
 
The mongoose is immune to snake venom; the equivalent to kevlar-lined clothing to us.
And the skunk?
 
 Another analogy for the mongoose is a safe room, but meh.
NATO 556

I'm making realistic assumptions. Not having guns wouldn't have made the cafeteria bombs mysteriously start to work, all they would have done is left the killers with knives to kill with.

 
 No, what you're proposing is mere speculation without evidence. Perhaps if the two didn't have guns then they would've paid precise attention to the bombs and then they would have gone off as they intended. Perhaps having illegally obtained firearms made them sloppy and thus saved more lives than were lost. There's no telling how many students would have been killed if the cafeteria bombing went as planned, it could've been a third of the student body for all we know.
 
 
If you can do that with a knife, then you can do it with a gun in exactly the same way. A gun can also kill at range.

 
 So why should I care if range gets factored into the equation as physical strength is removed? What difference does it make?
 
 
Your analogy is that if we could arm the chickens, then the foxes would stop attacking them. While this may be true, it also will have the effect of further arming the foxes, and encouraging more chickens to turn into foxes. We could also suitably defend the chickens by methods that do not stand open to abuse - extra fencing, putting a skunk amongst them, etc...

 
 I haven't seen anything like what you're suggesting happen. The criminals have guns, that's a constant. In turn the states one by one started letting citizens legally carry guns as well, that hasn't lead to an arms race like you're suggesting; if it had then we'd see criminals armed with AK-47s for everyday muggings instead of handguns like they're most often found in possession of.
 
 The current setting is criminals armed with handguns, citizens armed with handguns. Very, very few criminals are using long guns that offer superior range, firepower and accuracy. Your arms race analogy is flawed and wrong. It hasn't happened in the 20 years that concealed carry has been implemented.
 
 
And the skunk?

 
 What of it? What protects it more, it's chemical agent or its unique color pattern that advertises itself? The skunk is basically open carrying and displaying that it's armed and willing to hurt something or someone. After you've been sprayed by a skunk once you won't want to tangle with that animal again; just as being shot by the little old lady on the corner will convince you not to try that house ever again.
 
 
Another analogy for the mongoose is a safe room, but meh.

 
 A safe room is a non-moving bunker, the mongoose however is constantly on the move. Mongooses are banned in the states because of their destructive behavior and their killing nature. The situation is similar to that of criminals who wear body armor so when they're shot at they won't have lethal results. In this case the mongoose is the bad guy.
TRIGGER

iangb: Just a few points. First on stabbing someone, you only need to be within 20 feet of the intended victim. Most people don't have the reflexes to avoid an attack from under that distance, you can do it in app. 3 steps. If you don't believe me try it. A person with a gun that hasn't been formally trained is very unlikely to hit someone standing more than 25' distant. So line of site is only good if the shooter is extremely proficient with the firearm. Most shootings happen in less than 6' of separation.
 
 In my opinion had the perps of columbine had only bombs and knives the bombs being their first line of attack they would have made sure they worked and probably opted for something easier to make and allot more potent. all that's needed is one name McVeigh. I know how he did it and what he used I won't elaborate on how the bomb was made, but it is very easy to do with readily available materials. As it was their first line of offence were the guns the bombs were secondary.
 
 I don't like the analogy of the foxes and chickens. Lets just get down to facts iangb is it your contention that if law abiding people are exposed to guns that the exposure will have a tendency to make them more likely to become killers? Just want to know if I read you correctly.
jyoshu

We should absolutely NOT reinstate the assault weapons ban. It was one of the most flagrant examples of the federal govt. over-reaching, restricting constitutional rights. Obama has already made it clear he plans to reinstate it, and he has given indication of support toward banning firearms even farther.
 
 I think this is going to be a bad presidency for supporters of gun-based civil rights.
Charliegone

We should absolutely NOT reinstate the assault weapons ban. It was one of the most flagrant examples of the federal govt. over-reaching, restricting constitutional rights. Obama has already made it clear he plans to reinstate it, and he has given indication of support toward banning firearms even farther.
 
 I think this is going to be a bad presidency for supporters of gun-based civil rights.

 
 If Obama does not want to be re-elected by all means let him try. That's what made Congress go Republican in 94 thanks to Billy boys pushing of the AW ban. I think this time around though it will be difficult. Democrats from that time remember it well and they are not going to risk it IMHO.

If Obama does not want to be re-elected by all means let him try. That's what made Congress go Republican in 94 thanks to Billy boys pushing of the AW ban. I think this time around though it will be difficult. Democrats from that time remember it well and they are not going to risk it IMHO.

 
 The only thing I'm trying to understand is just how Clinton made it to a second term as US president. He was a support of the 94 ban bill, he signed it into law, but unlike his house and senate brethren he remained for a second term while everybody was getting voted out. How did that occur?
 
 My family and I didn't come into the country until after Bush took office. Maybe somebody can explain Clinton getting a second term to me.
Charliegone

The only thing I'm trying to understand is just how Clinton made it to a second term as US president. He was a support of the 94 ban bill, he signed it into law, but unlike his house and senate brethren he remained for a second term while everybody was getting voted out. How did that occur?
 
 My family and I didn't come into the country until after Bush took office. Maybe somebody can explain Clinton getting a second term to me.

 
 My understanding is he did lots of damage control after he signed it. He distanced himself from those libs that pushed the legislation, etc. Also Gingrich's Contract with America became rather popular and he capitalized on it. The only Democrats that kept their seats were those in relatively safe seats like Feinstein in California and Lautenberg from New Jersey.

 I agree 100% with this addition there are also many Blue Dog Dems that know if they go along with a ban it's out the door. Also remember that when the ban sunset only a couple Dems complained about it most looked the other way.
 
 My take why Clinton didn't get the heave ho was he was allotted 2 more years of damage control and a third party conservative candidate to strip some of the votes away. Remember the clinton never even got 50% of the vote.

There is a reason we have the right to bear arms in our constitution. It was so important to our founding fathers that it was the second amendment.
 
 Amendment II
 
 A well regulated militia, being necessary to the security of a free state, the right of the people to keep and bear arms, shall not be INFRINGED!
 
 Tell me how a gun ban doesn't infringe on my second amendment rights. I don't need a reason to own a gun it IS MY RIGHT!
 
 
 
 
 
 I cannot take credit for this but I feel it is relevant for the topic at hand.
 
 
 
 ------------------------------
 
 A Little Gun History Lesson 
 
 
 In 1929, the Soviet Union established gun control. From 1929 to 1953, about 20 million dissidents, unable to defend themselves, were rounded up and exterminated.
 
 ------------------------------
 
 In 1911, Turkey established gun control. From 1915 to 1917, 1.5 million Armenians, unable to defend themselves, were rounded up and exterminated.
 
 ---------------------------
 
 Germany established gun control in 1938 and from 1939 to 1945, a total of 13 million Jews and others who were unable to defend themselves were rounded up and exterminated
 
 -----------------------------
 
 China established gun control in 1935. From 1948 to 1952, 20 million political dissidents, unable to defend themselves, were rounded up and exterminated.
 
 ----------------------------
 
 Guatemala established gun control in 1964. From 1964 to 1981, 100,000 Mayan Indians, unable to defend themselves, were rounded up and exterminated.
 
 ------------------------------
 
 Uganda established gun control in 1970. From 1971 to 1979, 300,000 Christians, unable to defend themselves, were rounded up and exterminated.
 
 ------------------------------
 Cambodia established gun control in 1956. From 1975 to 1977, one million 'educated' people, unable to defend themselves, were rounded up and exterminated.
 
 -----------------------------
 
 Defenseless people rounded up and exterminated in the 20th Century because of gun control: 56 million.
 
 ------------------------------
 It has now been 12 months since gun owners in Australia were forced by new law to surrender 640,381 personal firearms to be destroyed by their own government, a program costing Australia taxpayers more than $500 million dollars. The first year results are now in:
 
 Australia-wide, homicides are up 3.2 percent
 
 Australia-wide, assaults are up 8.6 percent
 
 Australia-wide, armed robberies are up 44 percent (yes, 44 percent)!
 
 In the state of Victoria alone, homicides with firearms are now up 300 percent. Note that while the law-abiding citizens turned them in, the criminals did not, and criminals still possess their guns!
 
 While figures over the previous 25 years showed a steady decrease in armed robbery with firearms, this has changed drastically upward in the past 12 months, since criminals now are guaranteed that their prey is unarmed.
 
 There has also been a dramatic increase in break-ins and assaults of the ELDERLY. Australian politicians are at a loss to explain how public safety has decreased, after such monumental effort and expense was expended in successfully ridding Australian society of guns. The Australian experience and the other historical facts above prove it.
 
 Guns in the hands of honest citizens save lives and property and, yes, gun-control laws adversely affect only the law-abiding citizens.
 
 With Guns...........We Are "Citizens".
 Without Them........We Are "Subjects".
NATO 556

Something interesting in the news: Topeka police department breaks out the big guns
 
 Interesting article. Kindly notice the date: December 02, 2004.
 
 And now, notice the quote in the article: "In the last 10 years we've seen an increase in fire power by assailants, mostly high powered rifles," says Sgt. Dave Thomas with Topeka Police, "Shot guns and pistols can't match that."
 
 I can arrive at only two possibilities about this. Either the officer interviewed was wrong, or lying through his teeth; or the entire 10 years during with the 94 AWB was in effect, it didn't do a damn bit of good at hindering criminals.
